prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not keeping my husband undisturbed while he works from home.
My husband switched jobs within the past year or so and new job allows him to work from home  a few days a week.  He decided to set up his office in our bedroom.  I suggested he set up in the basement where he would be guaranteed silence and very little disruption.  He prefers to work from our bedroom because the view is better.  His job is 90% conference calls so while he is up there, I have to keep kids from disturbing him which basically means the whole top floor of our house is off limits while he is on calls.  It also means I can’t shower in my bathroom, do chores, put away laundry, or even take a nap when the baby is sleeping.  I also work from home but also take on most of the house chores and dealing with kids.  Him being up there negates my ability to take a damn shower or a poop in peace when I want to.   Since we have adequate space in the basement I told him that we would never bother him while he is down there ever but I can’t promise him silence if he stays in our bedroom. He says i am the asshole for not being quiet when he’s on calls while I think he is the asshole for not setting his office up in the dang basement. Please resolve our fight for us.  Thank you!
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking whether the person who wrote the story (the author) is in the wrong.

So, the situation is that the husband chose to set up his office in the bedroom instead of the basement, which the author suggested. The basement is quieter, but the husband likes the view. Because he works from home a few days a week, mostly on conference calls, the author has to manage the kids and prevent any disturbances. This means she can't use the top floor for chores, showers, etc., which affects her ability to work and take care of the household. The author works from home too and handles most of the housework and kids. She told him that if he's in the basement, they won't disturb him. But since he's in the bedroom, she can't guarantee silence, which leads to conflict.

Now, the key points here are about boundaries and mutual consideration. The husband chose a location that's inconvenient for the author. The author is trying to balance her work and family responsibilities. By setting up in the bedroom, he's limiting the author's access to shared spaces. The author is trying to set a boundary by saying if he moves to the basement, they can avoid the problem. But he's resistant.

Is the author in the wrong? Well, she's standing up for her needs. She's not being unreasonable by asking him to take his work to a less disruptive area. The husband's choice affects her ability to work and manage the household. The author isn't being inconsiderate; she's trying to find a solution. The husband's refusal to comply when there's an alternative (basement) might be the problem here. So, the author isn't in the wrong. The answer should be B.
